Dept. of Defense,</subfield><subfield code="c">2012.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="264" ind1=" " ind2="2"><subfield code="a">Oak Ridge, Tenn. :</subfield><subfield code="b">Distributed by the Office of Scientific and Technical Information, U.S. Dept. of Energy.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="336" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">text</subfield><subfield code="b">txt</subfield><subfield code="2">rdacontent</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="337" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">computer</subfield><subfield code="b">c</subfield><subfield code="2">rdamedia</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="338" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">online resource</subfield><subfield code="b">cr</subfield><subfield code="2">rdacarrier</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="500" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">Published through SciTech Connect.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="500" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">07/13/2012.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="500" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">"la-ur-12-22995"</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="500" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">DTRA Review ; 2012-07-19 - 2012-07-19 ; Los Alamos, New Mexico, United States.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="500" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">Gary, S. Peter; Liu, Kaijun; Winske, Dan.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="506" ind1=" " ind2="0"><subfield code="a">Free-to-read</subfield><subfield code="f">Unrestricted online access</subfield><subfield code="2">star</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="520" ind1="3" ind2=" "><subfield code="a">Banded whistler waves can be generated by the whistler anisotropy instability driven by two bi-Maxwellian electron components with T{sub ⊥}/T{sub ∥} > 1 at different T{sub ∥} For typical magnetospheric condition of 1 < ω{sub e}/Ω{sub e} < 5 in regions associated with strong chorus, upper-band waves can be excited by anisotropic electrons below ≈ 1 keV, while lower-band waves are excited by anisotropic electrons above ≈ 10 keV. Lower-band waves are generally field-aligned and substantially electromagnetic, while upper-band waves propagate obliquely and have quasi-electrostatic fluctuating electric fields. The quasi-electrostatic feature of upper-band waves suggests that they may be more easily identified in electric field observations than in magnetic field observations. Upper-band waves are liable to Landau damping and the saturation level of upperband waves is lower than lower-band waves, consistent with observations that lower-band waves are stronger than upper-band waves on average. The oblique propagation, the lower saturation level, and the more severe Landau damping together would make upper-band waves more tightly confined to the geomagnetic equator (</subfield><subfield code=" ">< ≈10{sup o}) than lower-band waves.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="536" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="b">AC52-06NA25396</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="650" ind1=" " ind2="7"><subfield code="a">Plasma Physics And Fusion Technology.</subfield><subfield code="2">edbsc</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="653" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">Anisotropy.</subfield><subfield code="a">Electric Fields.</subfield><subfield code="a">Electrons.</subfield><subfield code="a">Excitation.</subfield><subfield code="a">Geomagnetic Equator.</subfield><subfield code="a">Instability.</subfield><subfield code="a">Landau Damping.</subfield><subfield code="a">Magnetic Fields.</subfield><subfield code="a">Saturation.</subfield><subfield code="a">Whistlers.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="710" ind1="2" ind2=" "><subfield code="a">Los Alamos National Laboratory,</subfield><subfield code="e">researcher.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="710" ind1="1" ind2=" "><subfield code="a">United States.</subfield><subfield code="b">Department of Defense,</subfield><subfield code="e">sponsor.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="710" ind1="1" ind2=" "><subfield code="a">United States.</subfield><subfield code="b">Department of Energy.</subfield><subfield code="b">Office of Scientific and Technical Information,</subfield><subfield code="e">distributor.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="720" ind1="1" ind2=" "><subfield code="a">Gary, S. Peter</subfield><subfield code="4">aut</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="720" ind1="1" ind2=" "><subfield code="a">Liu, Kaijun</subfield><subfield code="4">aut</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="720" ind1="1" ind2=" "><subfield code="a">Winske, Dan</subfield><subfield code="4">aut</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="856" ind1="4" ind2="0"><subfield code="7">0</subfield><subfield code="u">http://www.osti.gov/servlets/purl/1046514/</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="949" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">Electronic resource</subfield><subfield code="w">ASIS</subfield><subfield code="c">1</subfield><subfield code="i">14737401-1001</subfield><subfield code="l">ONLINE</subfield><subfield code="m">ONLINE</subfield><subfield code="r">Y</subfield><subfield code="s">Y</subfield><subfield code="t">ONLINE</subfield><subfield code="u">4/17/2015</subfield><subfield code="o">.STAFF. "la-ur-12-22995" DTRA Review ; 2012-07-19 - 2012-07-19 ; Los Alamos, New Mexico, United States. Gary, S. Peter; Liu, Kaijun; Winske, Dan. Free-to-read Unrestricted online access star Banded whistler waves can be generated by the whistler anisotropy instability driven by two bi-Maxwellian electron components with T{sub ⊥}/T{sub ∥} > 1 at different T{sub ∥} For typical magnetospheric condition of 1 < ω{sub e}/Ω{sub e} < 5 in regions associated with strong chorus, upper-band waves can be excited by anisotropic electrons below ≈ 1 keV, while lower-band waves are excited by anisotropic electrons above ≈ 10 keV. Lower-band waves are generally field-aligned and substantially electromagnetic, while upper-band waves propagate obliquely and have quasi-electrostatic fluctuating electric fields. The quasi-electrostatic feature of upper-band waves suggests that they may be more easily identified in electric field observations than in magnetic field observations. Upper-band waves are liable to Landau damping and the saturation level of upperband waves is lower than lower-band waves, consistent with observations that lower-band waves are stronger than upper-band waves on average. The oblique propagation, the lower saturation level, and the more severe Landau damping together would make upper-band waves more tightly confined to the geomagnetic equator ( < ≈10{sup o}) than lower-band waves. Lower-band waves are generally field-aligned and substantially electromagnetic, while upper-band waves propagate obliquely and have quasi-electrostatic fluctuating electric fields. The quasi-electrostatic feature of upper-band waves suggests that they may be more easily identified in electric field observations than in magnetic field observations. Upper-band waves are liable to Landau damping and the saturation level of upperband waves is lower than lower-band waves, consistent with observations that lower-band waves are stronger than upper-band waves on average.
